lines.text: Blackfeet... proud injuns. They ain't gonna let no white man spy on their country. The only thing they are feared of is a white man's sickness.
What's that?

Grabs. White men don't see nothing pretty unless they want to grab it. The more they grab, the more they want to grab. It's like a fever and they can't get cured. The only thing for them to do is to keep on grabbin' until everything belongs to white men and then start grabbin' from each other. I reckon injuns got no reason to love nothing white.
Sure is big country. The only thing bigger is the sky.
They ain't deservin' of it, but I guess we better bury 'em.
Keep you eyes open. If you see anything, shoot. Don't bother to aim because you probably couldn't hit nothing no how.
Calloway, what do you think? Do you think they went away, huh?
They gone went. But the question is, will they stay gone went?
Boone, this is Teal's father, Chief Red Horse. Chief Red Horse wants to see you on account he wants to know how much you're gonna pay for his daughter.
Pay for Teal?
You married her, didn't ya? He gets paid.
Well, I reckon that's the custom.
Well, yes and no. In this particular case, it's yes.
Why did she want to grab this?
That's a Blackfoot scalp you got, and she knows it. Ain't you ever thought of why an injun takes a scalp?
Why?
To shame an enemy. The way she figures it, there's a Blackfoot brave somewhere who can't show his face to the hereafter until that thing is buried under the ground.
What's the noise about?
They're (Indians) celebrating your wedding.
Wedding?
You maybe don't know it, but you're a married man now.
Married? And I don't got nothing to say about it?
Wouldn't do you no good to say it.
A man leaves when he ain't got nothin' to stay for.
[while Jim was unconscious, Zeb and Boone amputated Jim's mangled finger]
Who's got it?
Got what?
My finger! What's a man going to do without his finger?
What do you want your finger for?
Zeb Calloway, didn't you tell me an injun can't go to heaven unless he's whole? Didn't ya?
That's right, I did.
You sure did.
That's what I heard. It sounds right, too, don't it?
Sounds right.
How can you go up there without your finger?
That's what I'm saying! Who's got it? Who's got it? Fine thing to do to a friend!

I remember once there being a trapper named Parker. He run smack into a big grizzly bear. The bear sure made a mess out of Parker before we killed it. Ripped one of his ears clear off. But this child just happened to have a needle and some of this deer sinew, just like we got here. Yeah, while his ear was still hot, I picked it up and sewed it back on his head. And it growed most as good as ever.
[and a little later]

I said growed most as good as ever. Not hardly. It seems I sewed Parker's ear on backwards. Yeah, he hated me until the day he died, on account of every time he heared a rattlesnake, he'd turn the wrong direction and step smack into it!

[Watching Boone play with the Indian scalp and annoyed with him for leaving Teal-Eye]
Playing with that scalp again. Whatd'ya give him that fer? That were a fool thing to do.
Worse than that, whole story were a lie.
What!
His brother weren't killed by no injun atall, fell in the river and drowned.
Huh... He wouldn't believe that!
Nobody would. I just talk too much.

[narrating]
Ain't it funny. Two men is friends. Then a girl comes along an... an pretty soon they ain't friends no more. And now with one of 'em walking out on what the other'n would give his right arm for, I kept wondering what they would do to settle it.
